elements.name: Comment18
elements.text: HP LASERJET 1536 DNF MFP, AVAYA PHONES

elements.name: Comment19
elements.text: Wireless Access Point Deployment

elements.name: Comment20
elements.text: A single Access Point (AP) can satisfactorily serve no more than approximately 20 concurrent clients.

elements.name: Comment21
elements.text: The effective limit could be more or less depending on required data throughput requirements.

elements.name: Comment22
elements.text: This is not related to “client associations”, which can be 200 or more.

elements.name: Comment23
elements.text: The single AP should be located as closely as possible to the most important or highest-density client areas.

elements.name: Comment24
elements.text: If the single AP isn’t able to service all areas, it is recommended to place additional APs rather than maximizing the transmit (Tx) power of the single AP.

elements.name: Comment25
elements.text: Running APs at high Tx power usually creates co-channel interference problems with neighboring APs –  yours and your neighbors’.

elements.name: Comment26
elements.text: For optimum performance an omnidirectional AP *must* be mounted horizontally, and in most cases should be mounted from 8’ to 9’ above the floor to a drop-ceiling rail.

elements.name: Comment27
elements.text: Mounting on a shelf, or under/on a table, or some other horizontal surface can be effective.

elements.name: Comment28
elements.text: Mounting above ceiling tiles is not recommended, due to signal scattering caused by the wires and rails; some types of ceiling tiles have foil lining, which scatters the signal.

elements.name: Comment29
elements.text: An AP should be mounted away from large metal surfaces, beams, conduits, ducts, etc.

elements.name: Comment30
elements.text: Typically, avoid placing APs in hallways; avoid having multiple APs in sight of each other; be mindful of APs on floors above and below when determining placement and channel selection.

elements.name: Comment31
elements.text: Keep in mind that “foreign” APs belonging to neighboring WLANs will impact your WLAN.  Conversely, your APs will impact those of your neighbors

elements.name: Condition21
elements.title: Is a Cat 5/5e/6 cable in place for the wireless access points?

elements.name: Comment32
elements.text: NO ACESS POINT
